title: Why does One-ForAll have "Majority" votes?
body:
Why is it that when I queue for One-For-All, the triple queue automatically gets to play whatever they want?
Why is it not just 20% chance per player?
Why should I be forced to play a specific champion and have **literally zero percent chance to play mine** (The client actually just says "Majority Vote, 0%)?
That doesn't seem fair _at all._

replies.body:
You see, I also have issues with this Majority in a Lottery Vote because "lottery" means there are odds. Locking out the odds because 3 people pick the same champ no longer makes it a lottery, and plus it defies math. Here's how math, and a lottery, works:

100%/5 = 20%
Each player, therefore, should have a vote weight of 20%.

If 3 players pick Yasuo, their combined vote weight is 60%.
That means there is still 40% vote weight unaccounted for. 
If the other 2 players pick Caitlyn and Jinx, there vote weight should be 20% each.
So the lottery odds should look like this:
60% Yasuo
20% Jinx
20%Caitlyn

What this SHOULD mean is that Yasuo is 10% more likely to be picked over Caitlyn or Jinx combined. What this SHOULD NOT mean is that Caitlyn and Jinx are *never* picked, because the math still allows for them to get picked, albeit at lower odds.
The current system is utterly stupid, and whoever designed the math calculations needs to go back to school and re-evaluate his or her life as a programmer.

But that's not how a lottery works, which is what the pick system calls itself. 
Even so, if 5 people choose different champs, there are odds for all 5 to be chosen. By that logic, which clearly whoever designed the pick system is not using, there should still be odds for 2 other players' picks if 3 pick the same champ. There is no sense in having a lockout on a *lottery* pick system. The same probability rules that apply in one scenario should apply in all scenarios. People not playing in premades should have *some* chance to play champions that the premade doesn't pick.

Let's assume that the aim of the voting system is to keep people as satisfied as possible with the end result. 

With the current system, by automatically giving the majority (generally three people) their pick, those people are guaranteed to be satisfied. The developers believe that it is better to satisfy three people and override the other two than to give everyone a chance but have the possibility of four people unsatisfied. 

I am not saying that it is the ideal system; I am presenting this from the developer's point of view. It is certainly unfortunate for people who have no chance against a triple queue, but in that case, at least those three are satisfied.

(I myself often queue in a party - we rarely agree on the same champ anyways so we end up individually picking the champs we think are best)

Good point.

Counter point: if the majority of players want to play champion x, but champion y is picked, then the majority is disappointed. However, if the majority all choose Champion y, then more people will be satisfied than those who chose champion x. Objectively speaking, there is a higher amount of satisfaction with letting the majority get their champion because they gain more than what is lost by the minority players in the queue.

Does it feel great for the minority? Probably not. But it is arguably better for 1-2 people to be dissatisfied than 3-4.
